words.meaning: The process or result of joining two or more things together to form a single entity.
examples: The restaurant's menu is a fusion of Asian and European cuisine.
Nuclear fusion is the process that powers the sun.

words.meaning: Incapable of producing any useful result; pointless.
examples: It was futile to argue with him; he had already made up his mind.
All their efforts to save the drowning man were futile.

words.meaning: Pointlessness or uselessness.
examples: She was struck by the futility of her situation.
The war was a lesson in the futility of violence.

words.meaning: An annoying person, especially one who provokes others into action by criticism.
examples: The journalist was a gadfly who was always questioning the government's policies.
He was a social gadfly, always stirring up trouble.

words.meaning: An unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment to its originator; a blunder.
examples: The politician made a gaffe during the debate, and it cost him the election.
He tried to cover up his gaffe with a nervous laugh.

words.meaning: To deny or contradict (a fact or statement).
examples: There is no gainsaying the fact that she is a talented artist.
No one dared to gainsay the king's command.

words.meaning: Bold, impudent behavior.
examples: He had the gall to ask for a raise after only being there for a week.
She was shocked by his gall.

words.meaning: (Of a person or their behavior) brave; heroic.
examples: The gallant knight saved the princess from the dragon.
He made a gallant effort to rescue the drowning child.

words.meaning: To shock or excite (someone) into taking action.
examples: The leader's speech galvanized the crowd into action.
The recent events have galvanized public opinion.

words.meaning: A device, action, or opening remark, typically one entailing a degree of risk, that is calculated to gain an advantage.
examples: His opening gambit in the chess game was to sacrifice a pawn.
The company's latest marketing gambit is to offer a free gift with every purchase.

words.meaning: To run or jump about playfully.
examples: The lambs were gamboling in the fields.
The children gamboled on the beach.

words.meaning: The complete range or scope of something.
examples: The actress was able to express a whole gamut of emotions.
The course covers the full gamut of topics in modern physics.

words.meaning: To reproduce (a message, sound, or transmission) in a confused and distorted way.
examples: The bad phone connection garbled his voice.
The news report garbled the facts of the story.

words.meaning: (Of a message, sound, or transmission) confused and distorted; unclear.
examples: The message on the answering machine was garbled.
He gave a garbled and incoherent account of what had happened.

words.meaning: Enormous.
examples: The giant had a gargantuan appetite.
It was a gargantuan task to clean up the city after the hurricane.

words.meaning: To gather or collect (something, especially information or approval).
examples: The movie has garnered several awards.
The politician is trying to garner support for his new policy.

words.meaning: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
examples: The garrulous old man would talk for hours about his past.
She was a garrulous and outgoing person.

words.meaning: Lacking ease or grace; unsophisticated and socially awkward.
examples: He was a gauche and clumsy young man.
Her gauche behavior embarrassed her friends.

words.meaning: Extravagantly bright or showy, typically so as to be tasteless.
examples: She wore a gaudy dress with too much jewelry.
The hotel was decorated in a gaudy and tasteless style.

words.meaning: (Of a person) lean and haggard, especially because of suffering, hunger, or age.
examples: The long illness left him looking gaunt and frail.
The gaunt faces of the refugees told a story of hardship.

words.meaning: A stout glove with a long loose wrist.
examples: The knight wore a metal gauntlet to protect his hand.
He had to run a gauntlet of reporters to get to his car.

words.meaning: A small mallet with which an auctioneer, a judge, or the chair of a meeting hits a surface to call for attention or order.
examples: The judge banged her gavel on the table to call the court to order.
The auctioneer brought the gavel down, and the painting was sold.

words.meaning: Nervously awkward and ungainly.
examples: He was a gawky teenager with long limbs.
She had a gawky and self-conscious manner.

words.meaning: Friendly and cheerful.
examples: He was a genial host who made everyone feel welcome.
She has a genial and outgoing personality.

words.meaning: The quality of having a friendly and cheerful manner; affability.
examples: She was known for her warmth and geniality.
The geniality of the host made the party a success.

words.meaning: The deliberate killing of a large number of people from a particular nation or ethnic group with the aim of destroying that nation or group.
examples: The world was shocked by the genocide in Rwanda.
The perpetrators of the genocide were brought to justice.

words.meaning: A style or category of art, music, or literature.
examples: Science fiction is his favorite genre of literature.
The movie does not fit neatly into any one genre.

words.meaning: Polite, refined, or respectable, often in an affected or ostentatious way.
examples: She was a genteel lady from a wealthy family.
The genteel atmosphere of the old hotel was charming.

words.meaning: Relevant to a subject under consideration.
examples: Please keep your comments germane to the topic of the discussion.
His personal life is not germane to his qualifications for the job.

words.meaning: (Of a seed or spore) to begin to grow and put out shoots after a period of dormancy.
examples: The seeds will germinate in a few days.
The idea for the new product began to germinate in his mind.

words.meaning: To manipulate the boundaries of (an electoral constituency) so as to favor one party or class.
examples: The ruling party was accused of trying to gerrymander the election.
The new electoral map was a clear case of gerrymandering.

words.meaning: The process of carrying or being carried in the womb between conception and birth.
examples: The period of gestation for an elephant is about 22 months.
The project had a long gestation period.

words.meaning: To use gestures, especially dramatic ones, instead of speaking or to emphasize one's words.
examples: He would often gesticulate wildly as he talked.
She gesticulated to the waiter to bring her the bill.

words.meaning: Causing great horror or fear; frightful or macabre.
examples: The accident was a ghastly sight.
He had a ghastly wound on his arm.

words.meaning: To cover thinly with gold.
examples: The dome of the cathedral was gilded with gold leaf.
He gilded the truth to make his story more interesting.

words.meaning: To try to improve what is already beautiful or excellent.
examples: Adding more decoration to the beautiful cake would be just gilding the lily.
The movie was already perfect, and the sequel just gilded the lily.

words.meaning: To encircle (a person or part of the body) with a belt or band.
examples: He girded his loins and prepared for the difficult task ahead.
The city was girded by a high wall.

words.meaning: The substance or essence of a speech or text.
examples: I didn't catch every word, but I got the gist of what he was saying.
Can you give me the gist of the article?

words.meaning: Relating to, resulting from, or denoting the presence or agency of ice, especially in the form of glaciers.
examples: The landscape was shaped by glacial erosion.
He moved at a glacial pace, taking forever to get ready.

words.meaning: Striking someone or something at an angle rather than directly.
examples: The car suffered a glancing blow in the accident.
He gave her a glancing look as he walked by.

words.meaning: Giving out or reflecting a strong or dazzling light.
examples: The glaring sun made it difficult to see.
It was a glaring error that should have been caught.

words.meaning: To extract (information) from various sources.
examples: She gleaned information from a variety of websites.
The reporter was able to glean some interesting facts from the interview.

words.meaning: (Of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow.
examples: He was a glib salesman who could talk anyone into buying anything.
Her glib excuses did not fool anyone.

words.meaning: To contemplate or dwell on one's own success or another's misfortune with smugness or malignant pleasure.
examples: He couldn't resist gloating over his victory.
It is not nice to gloat about your good fortune.

words.meaning: To have an angry or sullen look on one's face; scowl.
examples: He glowered at me when I told him the bad news.
She was glowering at her computer screen.

words.meaning: Past tense of glower; had an angry or sullen look on one's face.
examples: The angry cat glowered at the dog.
The manager glowered at the lazy employee.

words.meaning: Looking or feeling dejected; morose.
examples: He looked glum after hearing the bad news.
The team was in a glum mood after their defeat.

words.meaning: An excessively abundant supply of something.
examples: There is a glut of cheap apartments on the market.
The glut of oil has caused prices to fall.

words.meaning: Relating to knowledge, especially esoteric mystical knowledge.
examples: The Gnostic gospels offer a different perspective on early Christianity.
He was interested in Gnostic philosophy and mysticism.

words.meaning: To go against the natural direction or inclination of something.
examples: It goes against the grain for me to lie.
Her unconventional ideas often went against the grain.

words.meaning: To provoke or annoy (someone) so as to stimulate some action or reaction.
examples: He was trying to goad her into an argument.
The criticism goaded him into working harder.

words.meaning: A state of the skin caused by cold, fear, or excitement, in which small bumps appear on the surface as the hairs become erect.
examples: The scary movie gave me goosebumps.
I got goosebumps when I heard the beautiful music.

words.meaning: A narrow valley between hills or mountains, typically with steep rocky walls and a stream running through it.
examples: The river flows through a deep gorge.
He gorged himself on a huge meal.

words.meaning: Used to refer to something very light, thin, and insubstantial or delicate.
examples: The butterfly's wings were as delicate as gossamer.
The spider's web was a gossamer thread in the morning light.

words.meaning: To make (a groove, hole, or indentation) with or as if with a sharp tool or blade.
examples: He gouged a hole in the wall with a screwdriver.
The company was accused of gouging its customers with high prices.

words.meaning: A scale or a series of successive changes, stages, or degrees.
examples: The painting showed a subtle gradation of colors.
There is a gradation of difficulty in the exercises.

words.meaning: Practices, especially bribery, used to secure illicit gains in politics or business; corruption.
examples: The politician was accused of graft and corruption.
The company was involved in a massive graft scandal.

words.meaning: Splendor and impressiveness, especially of appearance or style.
examples: The palace was a building of great grandeur.
The grandeur of the mountains was breathtaking.

words.meaning: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
examples: The politician's speech was full of grandiloquent promises.
He had a grandiloquent and theatrical manner.

words.meaning: Impressive and imposing in appearance or style, especially pretentiously so.
examples: He had a grandiose plan to build a new city.
The grandiose mansion was a symbol of his wealth.
